catalyst.context: Photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to renewable hydrocarbon fuels is a promising strategy to address global energy issues; however, producing fuels like CH 4 is highly challenging under visible light.In this work, fabrication of a two-dimensional bentonite (2D-Bt) nanosheet mediated WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 Z-scheme heterojunction for highly selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to CH 4 under visible light has been investigated.The photocatalytic performance of the newly developed WO 3 -embedded 2D pillared Bt with 2D g-C 3 N 4 composite for selective photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to methane was studied using H 2 O as the reducing agent under visible light.WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 (WBCN) exhibits the highest photocatalytic activity for CH 4 production, which was 6.01, 6.76, and 25.30 times higher than using WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , and g-C 3 N 4 samples, respectively.Noticeably, WO 3 -coupled with g-C 3 N 4 was favorable for CO production; however, introducing Bt layered clay was in favor of methane formation during the CO 2 reduction process.Additionally, the Z-scheme of the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite with Bt as the electron moderator could promote photoinduced charge separation and redox ability of the separated charge carriers, resulting in excellent CO 2 reduction to CH 4 .The rate of reaction was dependent only on the external mass transfer due to surface reactions over the WBCN composite catalyst.With increasing photon flux, methane production was further enhanced due to the thermodynamically favorable process for the activation of CO 2 methanation reaction.Besides, good cycling ability was observed due to the presence of a layered clay structure, which was sustained in multiple cycles without obvious deactivation.This study provides a green clay based noble-metal-free approach to construct a structured composite photocatalyst with a Z-scheme charge carrier and would be beneficial for CO 2 reduction and other solar energy applications.

reducing agent in a fixed bed and gas-phase photoreactor system.WO 3 / Bt/g-C 3 N 4 exhibits excellent photoactivity for both CO and CH 4 productions during the CO 2 photoreduction process under visible-light irradiation.The highest yields of CO and CH 4 of 37.4 and 118.9 mol h -1 were obtained using 150 mg of photocatalyst under 20 mW cm -2 light intensity.The amount of CH 4 production over the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite was 5.98-, 6.74-, and 25.19-fold higher than its production over WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , and g-C 3 N 4 samples, respectively.The production of CO and CH 4 over the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite varied by using different amounts of catalyst loading, providing information that interaction between light irradiation and catalyst is very important to maximize photocatalytic activity.The production rate of CH 4 was increased to 177.9 mol h -1 using 100 mW cm -2 light intensity under the same reaction conditions.A 1.49-fold improvement in performance of the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite was observed by increasing light intensity from 20 to 100 mW cm -2 due to more production of charge carriers over the composite photocatalyst surface.Highest QYs of 20.106 and 1.875 for CH 4 and CO were achieved over the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite with a selectivity of 72.82 for methane formation.In general, the significantly enhanced photocatalytic performance of the composite catalyst was due Energy Fuels to the formation of the direct Z-scheme system with higher redox potential for photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 to CO and CH 4 under visible-light irradiation.The stability analysis further confirms continuous fuel formation over entire irradiation time and employing multiple cycles without any decrement in productivity.The findings of the present work are expected to be utilized for constructing the Z-scheme heterojunction system without using noble metals with controlled morphology for tailoring photoinduced CO 2 reduction to fuels and which would also be helpful for other solar fuel application. lamp.context: 2.1.Chemicals.Bentonite (Sigma-Aldrich, USA), melamine (Sigma-Aldrich, AR, purity 99), tungsten(VI) oxide (WO 3 , Acros, purity 99), and methanol (Merck, Reagent grade, Germany) were high-quality chemicals and were used as received. 2.2.Synthesis of the g-C 3 N 4 and Bt/g-C 3 N 4 Composite.In the first step, bulk graphitic carbon nitride (g-C 3 N 4 ) was fabricated using melamine powder as the precursor.Specifically, melamine (5 g), after placing in a ceramic crucible, was heated for 2 h at 550 C to get a sticky cake having a yellow color. 54The cake obtained was converted to fine powder by grinding with the help of a piston and mortal and after acid treatment, it was named as g-C 3 N 4 (CN).In the next step, the 2D pillared Bt coupled 2D g-C 3 N 4 heterojunction was synthesized through an ultrasonic-assisted impregnation approach.For this purpose, specific amounts of g-C 3 N 4 and Bt were dispersed in 20 mL of methanol through stirring and ultrasonic approach.Afterward, both the suspensions were mixed under continuous stirring and ultrasonicated for 60 min to get homogeneous texture.Finally, solids were separated through a centrifuge, and the sludge obtained was dried overnight in an oven at 100 C and named the Bt/ g-C 3 N 4 (BCN) composite. 2.3.Synthesis of WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 and WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 Composites.For the synthesis of the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 composite, the ultrasonic approach was employed.Typically, 0.5 g of g-C 3 N 4 was dispersed in methanol under vigorous stirring for 12 h.Afterward, WO 3 dispersed in methanol was added to the above suspension, and the mixture of WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 was ultrasonicated for 60 min for their uniform dispersion and finally centrifuged, dried overnight at 100 C under air flow, and named the WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 (WCN) composite. For the synthesis of the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite, a similar approach was employed as discussed above.First, g-C 3 N 4 and Bt, dispersed in methanol, were mixed together and ultrasonicated for their uniform dispersion (sample A).In parallel, WO 3 was dispersed in methanol and stirred for uniform dispersion and named sample B. Afterward, sample B was added to sample A under continuous stirring.The suspension was ultrasonicated for developing good interaction and uniform dispersion of the materials.Finally, the suspension was centrifuged, oven-dried at 100 C, and named the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 (WBCN) composite.The schematic illustration for the synthesis of Bt/g-C 3 N 4 and WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 is shown in Figure 1. microscope.The chemical bonding and oxidation states were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron microscopy (XPS) analysis, recorded with an Axis Ultra DLD Shimadzu system.The binding energy (BE) was the excitation source. 2.5.Photoactivity Test.The photocatalytic activity test for CO 2 reduction with H 2 O was conducted in a gas-phase photoreactor system with the catalyst uniformly distributed reactor type.context: 3.1.Characterization.XRD results of Bt, g-C 3 N 4 , WO 3 , BCN, and WBCN are presented in Figure 2a.In the XRD patterns of Bt, the characteristic peaks appeared at 2 of 7.01, 19.82, 26.62, 28.42, and 34.84, ascribed to the presence of bentonite clay.Two obvious XRD patterns for g-C 3 N 4 were observed with 2 of 13.15 and 27.45.The first peak at 2 of 13.15belongs to the (100), whereas another peak at 2 of 27.45reflects the (002) planes, both of which confirm the polymeric graphitic structure of g-C 3 N 4. 55 Similarly, several characteristic diffraction peaks of WO 3 that appeared at 2 of 23.12, 23.63, 24.36, 26.5, 28.77, 33.24, and 34.17correspond to WO 3 with the monoclinic phase (Card 01-083-0950) and similarly reported previously. 56For the Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite, all the characteristic peaks of Bt and g-C 3 N 4 appeared, confirming their good interaction without destroying their individual characteristics.Furthermore, in the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite, the obvious (002) peak of g-C 3 N 4 was weakened and shifted toward a higher value, while the (100) peak disappeared, confirming the exfoliation of layers.Besides, some Bt peaks disappeared, and prominent peaks were weakened, clearly indicating that the layered Bt structure has been exfoliated as expected.However, all the characteristic peaks of WO 3 in the composite appeared, an indication that the composite was successfully synthesized with good interaction among the individual components. The Raman spectra of the samples were acquired to identify their structure characteristics, as demonstrated in Figure 2b.For pristine WO 3 , the characteristic bands appeared at 131.57, 271.65, 716.76, and 806.68 cm -1 .The Raman peak at 271.65 cm -1 belongs to the bending vibration mode of W-O, whereas peaks at 716.76 and 806.68 cm -1 present the stretching vibration mode of O-W-O bands, which is similar to the literature. 34,57Similarly, all the Raman peaks of g-C 3 N 4 belong to the polymeric structure of graphitic carbon nitride.It is noticeable that there is a slight shift in Raman peaks for the BCN, WCN, and WBCN samples.The shifts in Raman peaks confirm their good interaction to develop heterojunction composites.Previously, a CdS/WO 3 /WS 2 composite has been reported with shifts in Raman peaks due to good interaction among the materials. 57This indicates that the WBCN composite was successfully constructed, which is beneficial to transport charge carriers for stimulating the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction process. The structures and morphologies of g-C 3 N 4 , WO 3 , Bt-loaded g-C 3 N 4 , and WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite samples were further examined using FESEM measurement.Figure 3a shows g-C 3 N 4 layers with uniform size and shape.Figure 3b shows the cubic structure of WO 3 with uniform size and shape, whereas Figure 3c further confirms the orthorhombic crystal structure of WO 3 , which would be beneficial for providing larger external active surface area.The bentonite micrograph reveals an obvious 2D layer structure as presented in Figure 3d.The Bt has a typical layered structure with irregular curves, and all the layers are compact together and similarly reported in the literature. 49fter coupling Bt with g-C 3 N 4 through the pillaring process, Bt layers become thinner, apart from each other, and are pillared with g-C 3 N 4 as demonstrated in Figure 3e,f.Obviously, 2D Bt layers are effectively pillared with 2D g-C 3 N 4 layers for constructing the 2D/2D heterojunction.More importantly, the surface became porous and rough, which provides a good interfacial interaction among the layered structures; thus, it confirms successful completion of the pillared process. 45This would be beneficial for efficient separation and transportation of photoinduced electrons and holes during the photocatalysis process.Figure 3g-i presents the morphology of the WO 3 /Bt/ g-C 3 N 4 composite.Evidently, WO 3 has been uniformly dispersed over the 2D/2D Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite, indicating a good interaction among the three components of the composite.Thus, the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite was successfully synthesized through a facile ultrasonication method and will be promising for stimulating optical and photocatalytic characteristics. The optical properties of WO 3 , Bt, g-C 3 N 4 , and their binary/ ternary composite heterostructures were conducted through UV-visible DRS, as displayed in Figure 7a.The absorption edges of pristine WO 3 and pure g-C 3 N 4 are estimated at around 450 nm, confirming their visible-light absorption.Bentonite has a wide range of light absorption in both UV and visible regions; however, higher light absorption is observed in the UV region.Furthermore, when Bt was pillared with g-C 3 N 4 , there was no significant effect on the change in the visible-light absorption edge, attributed to the typical light absorption of Bt derived from their layered structure characteristics.Similarly, coupling WO 3 with g-C 3 N 4 did not alter the band edge of visible-light absorption due to the same visible-light absorption characteristics of both the materials.After construction of the ternary WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite, the light absorption edge was somewhat shifted toward the UV region, probably due to UV-visible-light absorption characteristics of Bt in the composite.Previously, similar results have been reported while investigating a Mt-loaded g-C 3 N 4 /TiO 2 composite for photocatalytic hydrogen production. 47Furthermore, the band gap energy of photocatalysts is calculated using the Tauc equation as demonstrated in eq 1. A hv E ( ) ( ) where hv, , A, and E g are the photon energy, absorption coefficient, absorption constant, and optical energy band gap, respectively.The band gap energies were calculated from the plot of (ahv) 2 versus photon energy (hv) as demonstrated in Figure 7b.The band gap energies were estimated to be 2.74, 2.85, 2.90, 2.93, and 2.95 eV for the WO 3 , g-C 3 N 4 , Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , and WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 photocatalysts, respectively.It is obvious that visible-light absorption edges of pristine WO 3 and g-C 3 N 4 were not much affected with Bt loading.In the literature, band gap energies of 2.70 for g-C 3 N 4 and 2.60 eV for WO 3 have been reported.However, an increase in band gap energy of WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 was observed, which can be attributed to the presence of defect states of g-C 3 N 4 due to the incorporation of WO 3 . 29Similarly, a band gap energy of 2.70 eV for WO 3 has been reported. 33In another work, band gap energies of 2.80 and 2.87 eV were obtained for the WO 3 and RGO/WO 3 samples, respectively. 58All these Energy Fuels findings confirm the results of current work, whereas WO 3 coupled with g-C 3 N 4 would be beneficial to construct the Zscheme heterojunction system for efficient photocatalytic CO 2 reduction to fuels.The photoluminescence (PL) characterization was further conducted to determine charge carrier separation trends of the samples.Figure 7c divulges the relationship of PL intensities of pristine g-C 3 N 4 , WO 3 /g-C 3 N 4 , and Bt-mediated WBCN photocatalyst samples.The PL spectra were obtained at an excitation wavelength of 325 nm, and a broader peak in the range of 400 to 600 nm for all the samples was observed; however, peak intensity varied according to pure, binary, and ternary composite samples.The PL spectrum of pure g-C 3 N 4 shows the highest emission intensity, noticeably due to immediate recombination of electron and holes.The PL intensity of g-C 3 N 4 clearly declined after coupling with WO 3 due to faster charge carrier separation among the semiconductors.Comparatively, a lower charge carrier recombination rate was observed over Bt/g-C 3 N 4 , as evidenced by lower PL emission intensity, due to 2D/2D heterojunction development with superior charge carrier transportation.In the literature, lowered PL intensity over the CNTs/TiO 2 /MMT composite due to the prevented recombination rate by layered clay has been reported. 48Likewise, the PL intensity of g-C 3 N 4 / TiO 2 was significantly reduced by introducing 2D layered Mt clay because of faster charge carrier separation. 54Thus, layered clay materials are efficient for trapping and transporting charge carriers in the semiconductors due to the presence of transition-metal ions in their galleries. a surfacedependent chemical reaction and occurs by consuming electrons (e -) and holes (h ), which are produced over the photocatalyst surface with the involvement of light irradiation.This further demonstrates that there would be a good interaction between the three components of the photocatalytic reaction system (light, catalyst-exposed surface area, and reactants) to attain highest photocatalyst performance.Therefore, the efficiency of the WBCN composite photocatalyst was further explored under different amounts of catalyst loadings during CO 2 reduction with water at different times, and results are demonstrated in Figure 9. Figure 9a shows the production of CO, whereas highest production was observed with 150 mg catalyst loading, which gradually declined when loading amounts were increased to 250 mg.However, continuous CO production over irradiation time was observed, and production trends were consistent under all three loading amounts.The decrease in CO production with higher catalyst loading can be explained based on the following: (a) the catalyst surface was not fully utilized due to employing a fixed bed reactor, and only the upper surface of the catalyst was photoactivated for the generation of charge carriers, resulting in declined photocatalytic per unit mass of catalyst surface available; and (b) some amount of CO produced would be converted to methane through CO methanation due to higher efficiency of the composite catalyst for generating electrons.Thus, declined CO productivity with a higher amount of catalyst loading would be due to less utilization of the available catalyst surface and conversion of CO to CH 4 over the electron/hole-rich catalyst surface. Figure 9b presents the effect of catalyst loading for stimulating methane formation under visible-light irradiation.Using a small amount of catalyst loading (50 mg), CH 4 production was lower, which is obviously increased when the catalyst loading amount was increased to 150 mg.This increase in WBCN photoactivity for methane production was evidently due to more available catalyst surface area for the conversion of CO 2 /CO to methane.With the increase in catalyst loading, there would be more surface area available for more CO 2 uptake and capture of light irradiation, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic activity.For the conversion of CO 2 to CH 4 , eight electrons are required; however, CO can be converted to methane through CO methanation using six electrons.Thus, enhanced CH 4 production over the WBCN composite with higher loading would enable higher CO 2 adsorption with efficient production of charge carriers for methane formation through CO 2 /CO methanation with the involvement of eight/ six electrons.As expected, when catalyst loading was increased to 150 mg, CH 4 production declined and evolution rates were steady with time on stream.Any excessive loading may cause lower catalyst surface area exposed to light irradiation, resulting in declined photoactivity. Comparatively, trends for CO and CH 4 are different with various amounts of catalyst loading.This can be explained based on sorption competitions, higher light absorption, and multiple reactions for CO 2 conversion to CH 4 .With lower catalyst loading, only a small amount of CO 2 adsorption occurs with a lower amount of charge carrier production, resulting in production of both CO and CH 4 .However, when catalyst loading was increased, larger surface area would be available for CO 2 uptake for its conversion to CO.However, due to excessive availability of electrons, produced CO has potential for CH 4 formation through the methanation process with the involvement of six electrons.Any excessive loading (250 mg) resulted in declined production of both CO and CH 4 due to unexposed catalyst surface area for utilizing light irradiation and similarly reported in the literature. 65All these results demonstrate that catalyst loading not only enhances photoactivity but also has an impact on product selectivity during the CO 2 reduction process. Figure 10 shows the schematic illustrations for the mass transfer of CO 2 and H 2 O with external and internal mass transfer diffusion limitations in the presence of visible-light irradiation.Figure 10a shows the schematic illustration of different amounts of catalyst loading with reactants attached to the catalyst surface.Using a small amount of catalyst loading (50 mg), the reactor surface was not entirely covered with the catalyst, and thus, photon flux was not effectively consumed during the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction process.Using 150 mg of catalyst surface, higher adsorption of reactants (CO 2 , H 2 O) would be achieved due to a larger exposed catalyst surface to reactants and light absorption.Due to the higher sorption process with more photon flux utilization, the CO 2 reduction process was significantly enhanced with selective CO and methane formation under visible-light irradiation.Comparatively, with excessive loading of the catalyst (250 mg), bed height was increased; however, the catalyst surface exposed to reactants and light irradiation was decreased, resulting in lower production of CO and CH 4 per unit mass of catalyst employed.This was evidently because all the photocatalysts loaded inside the reactor was not fully consumed, resulting in declined productivity. All these findings are further discussed based on mass transfer and external/internal diffusions as illustrated in Figure 10d.In the thermal process of CO 2 reduction, the rate of reaction is dependent on seven steps, which include external diffusion, internal diffusion, adsorption of reactants, and surface reactions.In photocatalysis, the reaction rate is dependent on the catalyst surface exposed to reactants and light irradiation and is independent of internal diffusion of reactants inside the pores and channels.Thus, the performance of the photocatalyst is dependent on reactants attached to the catalyst external surface and light irradiation absorption over the catalyst surface.With increasing catalyst loading, the catalyst surface exposed to light irradiation would be reduced; however, internal mass transfer would be proficient, which would not be beneficial for the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction process.Comparatively, using a very small amount of catalyst loading, external mass transfer would be very efficient; however, adsorption of reactants will be the rate-limiting steps.Similarly, the rate-limiting step is dependent on the consumption of photon flux entering into the reactor, which is indirectly dependent on the efficiency of light absorption and production of photoinduced electrons and holes over the catalyst surface.In addition, charge carrier separation and its transportation toward the catalyst surface for dynamic CO 2 conversion and water splitting also influence the rate of reaction.Using the WBCN composite with optimized catalyst loading, there would be more external mass transfer and surface adsorption of reactants with photon flux utilization and proficient charge carrier separation, resulting in significantly enhanced CO and methane formation. 3.2.3.Effect of the Reducing Agent.The performance of the WO 3 /Bt/g-C 3 N 4 composite for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction was further investigated under different reducing agents.The reducing agents employed were pure water, mixture of 10 acetic acid-water solution, and 10 methanol-water solution.For this purpose, CO 2 gas was regulated to pass through these solutions to carry either water-methanol or water-acetic acid vapors before entering into the photoreactor.Besides, controlled experiments were also conducted without using CO 2 in the feed mixture but using only nitrogen to carry water-methanol vapors into the photoreactor.The photocatalytic production of CO and CH 4 during CO 2 reduction with different types of feed mixtures is demonstrated in Figure 11.Using only water vapors with nitrogen, production of CH 4 or CO was not detected.Similarly, using nitrogen with 10 methanol-water vapors, a smaller amount of CO was produced with trace amounts of CH 4 production. On the other hand, when acetic acid and methanol were added to water, production of CO and CH 4 was increased.However, the highest photoactivity of the WBCN composite was obtained when CO 2 reduction was conducted with water vapors only.This was obviously due to the activation of reforming reaction of acetic acid and methanol for CO 2 and hydrogen production, instead of CO 2 reduction to CO and CH 4 .Thus, production of CO during water-methanol vapors without CO 2 in the feed mixture would be due to the following: first, CO 2 would be produced during methanol steam reforming, which was finally converted to CO with the involvement of hydrogen during the photocatalysis process.Recently, we have investigated photocatalytic water splitting with methanol as the reducing agent and observed the production of CO 2 in addition of hydrogen. 66This confirms that methanol was not favorable for CH 4 production, and similarly, the photocatalyst was cleaned, and any carboncontaining products were produced during CO 2 reduction under light irradiation. 3.2.4.Effect of Light Intensity and Thermodynamic Analysis.Since photoinduced CO 2 reduction is an endothermic reaction, which is not possible to occur naturally under standard reaction conditions.To break the thermodynamic endothermic barrier of chemical reaction, the input energy can be provided through heat, electricity, or light source (UV-or visible-light irradiation).The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction reaction can be conducted in standard conditions with the use of light energy, but the extent of photocatalytic reaction is entirely dependent on the amounts of photogenerated charge carriers and their effective utilization.Therefore, the performance of the WBCN composite photocatalyst was further investigated at different light intensities (20 and 100 mW cm -2 ) as demonstrated in Figure 12a,b.Evidently, CO and CH 4 productions were increased by varying the light intensity, and trends were steady with time on stream.The productions of CO and CH 4 were increased by 1.77-and 1.49-fold by varying the light intensity from 20 to 100 mW cm -2 , respectively.The increase in photocatalytic activity with higher light intensity was obviously due to promoting photoinduced electrons and holes for stimulating photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 and water oxidation process over the WBCN composite photocatalyst.Comparatively, light intensity was increased by 5-fold (20 to 100 mW cm -2 ), but photoactivity was enhanced only by 1.5-to-2.12fold for CH 4 and CO production, respectively.This demonstrates that all the light irradiation was not fully utilized by the photocatalyst during the CO 2 reduction process.This would be possibly because not all the catalysts exposed to the catalyst surface and the light absorption were not efficient due to using a fixed bed photoreactor system and similarly reported in the literature. 61ll these findings confirm that light intensity is beneficial for enhancing photocatalytic performance; however, full utilization of light intensity depends on catalyst surface area exposed to light irradiation, which is directly dependent on the design of the photoreactor system. on the production of electrons and holes, which has a direct relation with the photon flux utilization.When light strikes over the catalyst surface, it is consumed for the generation of charge carriers, enabling CO 2 reduction and water oxidation processes.A 818 kJ mol -1 minimum energy is required to cross the energy barrier among the reactants (CO 2 ) and products (CH 4 ) during CO 2 reduction to CH 4 . 67n addition, conversion of CO 2 to produce CO and methane cannot be possible if the water oxidation process is not efficient.This is because both electrons and protons are required for CO and methane production during the CO 2 reduction process.Previously, it was reported that more energy is required for water splitting to produce hydrogen compared to CO 2 reduction for energy barrier for the conversion of CO 2 to CO and methane can be reduced by increasing input energy, enabling enhanced methane formation through CO 2 and CO methanation. 3.2.5.Quantum Yield
